definition: rice bowl/fig. livelihood/job/way of making a living

sentences.english: Economists who ignore the recent rise in unemployment deserve to lose their jobs.
sentences.chinese: 忽视最近失业增加经济学家们，活该丢掉饭碗。

sentences.english: Firstly, and most importantly, don't put your chopsticks upright in the rice bowl.
sentences.chinese: 最为重要的是，不要把筷子直插在饭碗里。

sentences.english: I lost my job, and I got robbed on the way home.
sentences.chinese: 我丢了饭碗，而且在回家路上遭到了抢劫。

sentences.english: Yes you do care because they may have your lunch.
sentences.chinese: 你一定要关心，他们管住你的饭碗的。

sentences.english: The “European model” of generous social benefits and secure jobs is besieged.
sentences.chinese: 高福利和铁饭碗的欧洲模式危机重重。

sentences.english: All contract workers worry about the insecurity of their "paper rice bowl".
sentences.chinese: 这个厂的合同制工人都曾担心“纸饭碗”不牢靠。

sentences.english: When a large company gets bought out you wonder about your job.
sentences.chinese: 一家大公司被别人收买购，你自然担心你的饭碗。

sentences.english: Well but that fellow would lose his job then?
sentences.chinese: 不过，那样一来就会砸掉此人饭碗了吧？

sentences.english: The vacant bowl that tooks a see 1 eye flank, this just expiration a weep of relief.
sentences.chinese: 看了看一眼旁边的空饭碗，这才松了一口气。

sentences.english: Steal a man's job, will you?
Let me tell you, I can't quit this one. And I can't get the time off.
sentences.chinese: 让我跟你说，我不能扔掉这个饭碗。

sentences.english: "i know, " celia said. "it will probably cost my job. "
sentences.chinese: “我知道，”西莉亚说，“很可能会砸掉我的饭碗。”

sentences.english: B: I lost my job and I got robbed on the way home.
sentences.chinese: 我丢了饭碗，而且在回家路上遭到了抢劫。
结果现在巴茨也丢了饭碗。

sentences.english: Cf. In the end, it cost the company thousands—and it made me lose my job.
sentences.chinese: 这最终使公司损失了几千元钱，最后也让我丢了饭碗。

sentences.english: Hiddink's reputation now needs remedial work although he will not lack for offers of employment.
sentences.chinese: 尽管饭碗不愁，但希丁克可得好好挽回自己的名声了。

definition: to lose/to throw away/to discard/to cast away
to come off sentry duty/to lay off (a worker)/laid-off
lit. to eat from government coffers/to serve as a government employee/to live off government money
to support one's family (idiom); to have difficulty feeding a family
the people one depends upon for one's livelihood/one's bread and butter
